newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey calls up rebel leader for national service.
newsitem.headline: Turkey calls up rebel leader for national service.

text.p: Turkey has called on Kurdish separatist rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan to return to the country to do his military service or face losing his citizenship.

Ocalan who has led a violent campaign by the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) for Kurdish self-rule from Turkey since 1984 was among those listed in a government warning published in the official gazette on Wednesday.
"The following people who do not reside in Turkey...and have not to this date completed their military service will be subject to the following ruling:

"It is announced that if they do not come to Turkey and...apply to do their military service in three months, procedings will be started to be remove their Turkish citizenship," the announcement said.
Ocalan who has been missing since 1980 ordered the PKK's first violent action 13 years ago on Friday, with an attack on two gendarmerie posts in the mainly Kurdish southeast.
Since then more than 26,000 people have been killed in the ensuing conflict with the Turkish security services.
Friday's anniversary is usually a time of hightened tension and increased security alerts throughout the country in fear of further attacks marking the day.
Ocalan is alleged to reside in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa Valley in Lebanon. He has not known to have personally taken part in any of the PKK's attacks.
